slides.content:
# Introduction to Cell Biology ðŸ”¬

Welcome to **Cell Biology** - the study of life's basic building blocks!

## What you'll learn:
- **Cell Structure** - Organelles and their functions
- **Cell Membrane** - Transport and signaling
- **Cell Division** - Mitosis and meiosis
- **Cellular Respiration** - Energy production
- **Photosynthesis** - Energy capture

> ðŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** Your body contains about 37 trillion cells, and they're constantly dividing!

## The Cell Theory

1. All living things are made of cells
2. Cells are the basic unit of structure and function
3. All cells come from pre-existing cells

## Cell Types

| Feature | Prokaryote | Eukaryote |
|---------|------------|----------|
| Nucleus | No membrane | Membrane-bound |
| Size | 1-10 Î¼m | 10-100 Î¼m |
| Organelles | Few, simple | Many, complex |
| DNA | Circular | Linear chromosomes |
| Examples | Bacteria | Plants, animals, fungi |

## Why Study Cells?
- ðŸ¥ Understanding disease
- ðŸ’Š Drug development

Let's explore the microscopic world!

slides.title: Cell Structure - Organelles
slides.content:
# Cell Organelles ðŸ­

## Major Organelles

### Nucleus - Control Center
- Contains DNA (genetic information)
- Surrounded by nuclear envelope (double membrane)
- Nucleolus makes ribosomes

### Mitochondria - Powerhouse
- Site of cellular respiration
- Produces ATP (energy currency)
- Has own DNA (maternal inheritance)
- Double membrane

### Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER)

| Type | Structure | Function |
|------|-----------|----------|
| Rough ER | Ribosomes attached | Protein synthesis |
| Smooth ER | No ribosomes | Lipid synthesis, detox |

### Golgi Apparatus - Shipping Center
- Modifies, packages, ships proteins
- Stacks of flattened membranes
- Creates lysosomes

### Lysosomes - Recycling Center
- Contains digestive enzymes
- Breaks down waste, old organelles
- "Suicide bags" of the cell

### Ribosomes - Protein Factories
- Made of RNA and protein
- Free or bound to ER
- Read mRNA, build proteins

## Quick Reference

| Organelle | Main Function |
|-----------|---------------|
| Nucleus | DNA storage, control |
| Mitochondria | ATP production |
| Ribosome | Protein synthesis |
| Golgi | Package and ship |
| Lysosome | Digestion |
| ER | Synthesis |

> ðŸŽ¯ **Memory Tip:** Think of the cell as a factory with specialized departments!

slides.title: Plant vs Animal Cells
slides.content:
# Plant vs Animal Cells ðŸŒ±ðŸ¾

## Key Differences

| Feature | Plant Cell | Animal Cell |
|---------|------------|-------------|
| Cell wall | Present (cellulose) | Absent |
| Chloroplasts | Present | Absent |
| Central vacuole | Large, central | Small, multiple |
| Shape | Regular, rectangular | Irregular, round |
| Centrioles | Absent (usually) | Present |
| Lysosomes | Rare | Common |

## Plant-Specific Structures

### Cell Wall
- Made of cellulose
- Provides rigidity and support
- Outside the cell membrane
- Gives plants their structure

### Chloroplasts
- Site of photosynthesis
- Contains chlorophyll (green pigment)
- Double membrane
- Own DNA

### Central Vacuole
- Stores water, nutrients, waste
- Maintains turgor pressure
- Can fill 90% of cell volume

## Animal-Specific Features

### Centrioles
- Organize spindle fibers in cell division
- Made of microtubules

### Lysosomes
- More developed in animals
- Important for immune function

slides.title: Cell Membrane
slides.content:
# The Cell Membrane ðŸ§«

## Fluid Mosaic Model

The membrane is like a "sea of lipids with floating proteins."

```
   Outside cell
   ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
       â—‹  â—‹  â—‹  â—‹     Proteins
   â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶   Phospholipid bilayer
   â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶â•¶
       â—‹     â—‹
   ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
   Inside cell (cytoplasm)
```

## Phospholipid Bilayer

### Structure
- **Hydrophilic head** - Loves water, faces outside
- **Hydrophobic tails** - Hate water, face inward

### Properties
- Selectively permeable
- Fluid (molecules can move)
- Self-healing

## Membrane Proteins

| Type | Location | Function |
|------|----------|----------|
| Integral | Span membrane | Transport, signaling |
| Peripheral | Surface only | Enzymes, support |
| Channel | Create pores | Ion/water passage |
| Carrier | Bind molecules | Active transport |
| Receptor | Outer surface | Signal reception |

## Other Components

### Cholesterol (Animal cells)
- Stabilizes membrane fluidity
- Maintains flexibility

### Carbohydrates
- Attached to proteins/lipids
- Cell recognition
- Forms glycocalyx

## Functions of Cell Membrane

1. **Barrier** - Controls what enters/exits
2. **Communication** - Receptors and signals
3. **Recognition** - Cell identification
4. **Attachment** - Cell-cell connections

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** "Fluid mosaic" - components can move, like boats on a sea!

slides.title: Membrane Transport
slides.content:
# Membrane Transport ðŸš¢

## Passive Transport (No energy)

### Diffusion
- Movement from HIGH to LOW concentration
- No energy required
- Examples: Oâ‚‚, COâ‚‚ crossing membrane

### Osmosis
- Diffusion of WATER
- Water moves toward higher solute concentration

| Solution | Water Movement | Cell Effect |
|----------|----------------|-------------|
| Hypotonic | Water in â†’ | Swells/bursts |
| Isotonic | Equal | Normal |
| Hypertonic | Water out â†’ | Shrinks |

### Facilitated Diffusion
- Uses protein channels/carriers
- Still HIGH â†’ LOW
- Examples: Glucose, ions

## Active Transport (Uses energy)

### Primary Active Transport
- Uses ATP directly
- Example: Sodium-potassium pump

```
Naâº/Kâº Pump:
3 Naâº out â†’
â† 2 Kâº in
+ 1 ATP used
```

### Secondary Active Transport
- Uses gradient from primary transport
- "Piggyback" transport

## Bulk Transport

| Type | Direction | Mechanism |
|------|-----------|----------|
| **Endocytosis** | Into cell | Membrane engulfs |
| - Phagocytosis | "Cell eating" | Solids |
| - Pinocytosis | "Cell drinking" | Liquids |
| **Exocytosis** | Out of cell | Vesicle fuses with membrane |

## Summary

| Method | Energy | Direction |
|--------|--------|----------|
| Diffusion | No | High â†’ Low |
| Osmosis | No | Toward solute |
| Facilitated | No | High â†’ Low |
| Active | Yes (ATP) | Low â†’ High |

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Cells use energy to maintain concentration differences!

# Cellular Respiration âš¡

Converting glucose to ATP (energy)!

## Overall Equation

```
Câ‚†Hâ‚â‚‚Oâ‚† + 6Oâ‚‚ â†’ 6COâ‚‚ + 6Hâ‚‚O + ~36-38 ATP
Glucose + Oxygen â†’ Carbon dioxide + Water + Energy
```

## Three Stages

### 1. Glycolysis (Cytoplasm)

```
Glucose (6C) â†’ 2 Pyruvate (3C)

â€¢ Uses 2 ATP
â€¢ Produces 4 ATP
â€¢ Net gain: 2 ATP
â€¢ Produces 2 NADH
â€¢ No oxygen needed
```

### 2. Krebs Cycle (Mitochondrial matrix)

```
Pyruvate â†’ COâ‚‚ + ATP + NADH + FADHâ‚‚

â€¢ Produces 2 ATP
â€¢ Produces 6 NADH, 2 FADHâ‚‚
â€¢ Releases COâ‚‚
â€¢ Requires oxygen (indirectly)
```

### 3. Electron Transport Chain (Inner mitochondrial membrane)

```
NADH/FADHâ‚‚ â†’ 32-34 ATP

â€¢ Uses oxygen as final acceptor
â€¢ Produces water
â€¢ Most ATP made here!
```

## ATP Summary

| Stage | Location | ATP |
|-------|----------|-----|
| Glycolysis | Cytoplasm | 2 |
| Krebs Cycle | Matrix | 2 |
| ETC | Inner membrane | 32-34 |
| **Total** | | **36-38** |

## Aerobic vs Anaerobic

| Feature | Aerobic | Anaerobic |
|---------|---------|----------|
| Oxygen | Required | Not needed |
| ATP yield | 36-38 | 2 |
| End products | COâ‚‚, Hâ‚‚O | Lactate or ethanol |
| Efficiency | High | Low |

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Most ATP comes from the electron transport chain!

slides.title: Cell Cycle and Mitosis
slides.content:
# Cell Cycle & Mitosis ðŸ”„

## The Cell Cycle

```
       G1 (Growth)
          â†“
    S (DNA replication)
          â†“
       G2 (Growth)
          â†“
       M (Mitosis)
          â†“
      Cytokinesis
```

## Interphase (G1, S, G2)

| Phase | Events |
|-------|--------|
| G1 | Cell grows, normal functions |
| S | DNA replication |
| G2 | Preparation for division |

## Mitosis (PMAT)

### Prophase
- Chromosomes condense
- Nuclear membrane dissolves
- Spindle fibers form

### Metaphase
- Chromosomes line up at **M**iddle
- Spindle attaches to centromeres

### Anaphase
- Chromosomes pulled **A**part
- One chromatid to each pole

### Telophase
- Nuclear membranes re-form
- Chromosomes decondense
- Two nuclei visible

### Cytokinesis
- Cytoplasm divides
- Two daughter cells
- Animal: Cleavage furrow
- Plant: Cell plate forms

## Result of Mitosis

```
1 Cell (2n) â†’ 2 Cells (2n each)
          Identical copies!
```

## Purpose of Mitosis

- Growth
- Repair
- Asexual reproduction
- Replacement of dead cells

> ðŸŽ¯ **Memory Trick:** PMAT - Prophet Met A Tyrant!

slides.title: Meiosis
slides.content:
# Meiosis ðŸ§¬

Producing sex cells (gametes) with half the chromosomes!

## Overview

```
1 Cell (2n) â†’ 4 Cells (n each)
    Diploid      Haploid
                 (Genetically different!)
```

## Meiosis I - Reduction Division

### Prophase I
- Chromosomes condense
- Homologous pairs find each other
- **Crossing over** occurs!

### Metaphase I
- Homologous pairs line up
- Random orientation (independent assortment)

### Anaphase I
- Homologous pairs separate
- One of each pair to each pole

### Telophase I / Cytokinesis
- Two cells form
- Each cell is haploid (n)

## Meiosis II - Like Mitosis

- Prophase II â†’ Metaphase II â†’ Anaphase II â†’ Telophase II
- Sister chromatids separate
- Result: 4 haploid cells

## Sources of Genetic Variation

### 1. Crossing Over
- Exchange of DNA between homologs
- Creates new gene combinations

### 2. Independent Assortment
- Random orientation of pairs
- 2Â²Â³ = 8 million combinations!

### 3. Random Fertilization
- Any sperm + any egg

## Mitosis vs Meiosis

| Feature | Mitosis | Meiosis |
|---------|---------|--------|
| Divisions | 1 | 2 |
| Daughter cells | 2 | 4 |
| Ploidy | 2n â†’ 2n | 2n â†’ n |
| Identical? | Yes | No |
| Purpose | Growth | Gametes |

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Meiosis creates genetic diversity essential for evolution!
